mxfile.agent: Mozilla/5.0 (X11; Linux x86_64; rv:109.0) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/111.0

mxCell.value: 1. Client makes HTTP request with ID token (JWT) in authorization header.
3. Identification service verifies ID token and extracts PersistentSession ID.
2. Gateway forwards request to identification service.
4. Identification service fetches corresponding PersistentSession from PersistentSession service.
5. Identification service returns UserAccount ID, roles, and creation time of PersistentSession to gateway.
6. Gateway forwards original request with UserAccount ID, roles, and creation time of PersistentSession to appropriate service.
3. Authentication service checks request body to determine which flow to execute (credential or refresh token login). Credentials are found, so credential login flow starts.

5. If UserAccount query is successful, Authentication service takes password from request body, concatenates salt from UserAccount, and hashes it. Result is compared with hash from UserAccount. If they don't match, Authentication service responds to client with failure to authenticate (401).

6. If hashes match, Authentication service generates unique refresh token and PersistentSession entry. ID token (JWT) is generated with PersistentSession ID and creation time (current time) embedded in the payload.
1. Client makes POST request to /api/login. Body contains credentials (username and password).
2. Gateway forwards request to Authentication service.

4. Authentication service invokes UserAccount service to fetch UserAccount. Username in request body is used to query via name. System role is used in order to prevent UserAccount service from erasing password hash and salt from returned UserAccount. If no UserAccount exists with given username, Authentication service responds to client with failure to authenticate (401).
7. Authentication service responds to client with success (200), embedding refresh token and ID token in body.
3. Authentication service checks request body to determine which flow to execute (credential or refresh token login). Refresh token is found, so refresh token flow starts.

4. Authentication service uses refresh token in request body to query database for PersistentSession. If no match is found or match is expired, Authentication service responds to client with failure to authenticate (401).
5. If match is found, Authentication service generates ID token (JWT) with PersistentSession ID and creation time embedded in the payload.
1. Client makes POST request to /api/login. Body contains refresh token.
2. Gateway forwards request to Authentication service.
6. Authentication service responds to client with success (200), embedding ID token in body.
3. Authentication service uses refresh token from request body to delete any matching PersistentSession entry from database.
1. Client makes POST request to /api/logout. Body contains refresh token.
2. Gateway forwards request to Authentication service.

3. Authentication service extracts ID token (JWT) from request's authorization header. Token is verified via standard JWT procedures. Service extracts PersistentSession ID. If request does not contain token or verification fails, empty authority object is generated and returned to gateway.

4. Authentication service uses extracted ID to fetch PersistentSession from database. If no entry is found or entry is expired, ID token is considered as invalid and empty authority object is returned to gateway.
5. Authentication service uses UserAccount ID, roles, and creation time (equivalent to login time) of PersistentSession to construct authority object.
2. Gateway forwards request to Authentication service for client identification.
6. Authentication service returns authority object to gateway.
7. Gateway forwards original request with authority object to original destination.
8. Service uses authority object to determine whether client is authorized to execute request.

4. UserAccount service checks authority object to verify that client has at least one of following roles: system, admin, and user. If not, request is denied (401). If only user role exists, UserAccount service also verifies that UserAccount ID from authority object matches target ID specified for delete query. If not, request is denied (401).
6. If all conditions are met, UserAccount service deletes UserAccount entry that corresponds to target ID specified in query. If no such entry exists, UserAccount service responds with failure (404).
5. UserAccount service checks login time from authority object. If login time is too old (configurable threshold), request is denied (401).
1. Client makes DELETE request to /api/account with ID token in authorization header. ID of target UserAccount is specified as query parameter as such: /api/account?id=123
3. Gateway forwards request with authority object to UserAccount service.

7. UserAccount service invokes Authentication service to purge all PersistentSession entries that correspond to deleted UserAccount entry. UserAccount service provides ID of deleted UserAccount entry.
8. UserAccount service responds to client with success (200).
